data.title: Tennis champ David Nalbandian cheats death in spectacular rally crash in Argentina
data.meta_description: The 34-year-old ex-Wimbledon finalist rolled twice in his vehicle before he and his co-driver were helped out by shocked fans
data.text:
Former tennis star David Nalbandian cheated this weekend after his rally car rolled twice during an event in his native Argentina.

The 34-year-old, an ex-Wimbledon finalist and world number three at the height of his career, lost control of his vehicle during a national competition yesterday.

Footage taken by spectators showed his Chevrolet Agile rolling twice before ending up on its side.

He and his co-driver were helped out of the battered car by fans who at first feared the worst.

Miraculously, both were unhurt.

Nalbandian, runner-up at the 2002 Wimbledon final to Lleyton Hewitt, was reunited with his family soon after and boasted later in the day he was relaxing in a swimming pool with his daughter.

The former tennis player decided to try his hand at rally driving after retiring from tennis in 2013.

The dramatic crash happened in San Justo in the province of Entre Rios around 200 miles from the Argentinian capital Buenos Aires.

He was taking part in the Copa Maxi Rally, part of the national rally calendar.

Speaking earlier this year of his decision to test himself as the wheel, he said: “Tennis was my job and racing is a hobby. It’s very different.

"I don’t have pressure here. I am learning and trying to do my best but not as a professional.”

He walked away from a spectacular crash in April last year in which his car was also left a write-off after flipping several times.

Nalbandian turned professional aged 18 and is the only Argentinian tennis player in history who ever reached the semi-finals or better at all four Grand Slam tournaments.

He announced his retirement on October 1 2013 after a shoulder op sidelined him for much of the season.

He famously landed a line judge in hospital in the final of the Aegon Championships at the Queen’s Club in London in 2012 after kicking an advertising board which struck him on the shin.

He ended up forfeiting his prize money and being docked an additional 150 ranking points by the ATP.
